Finally got my new hinges and door parts this week and got my half doors all put together and ready for spring. Now I don't have to use my ugly (and somewhat rusty) red full doors. Somehow I managed to stop it from rusting from all the salt and crap here in Ohio this winter also.

WRITING.TITLE: Finally got my YJ (kinda) cleaned up

WRITING.TEXT: It's not a hinge problem. I just replaced my old rusty hinges with new stainless steel ones yesterday and adjusted them every which way and it has the same issue. This problem has me stumped because the passenger side is perfectly adjusted and works great, but the driver side doesn't. I currently have it shimmed with washers between the upper and lower doors on the bolt, and that somewhat fixed it.
And yeah, those are similar to mine.

There is no space, but they hit the side of the hard top when I close the doors. My hinges are adjusted all the way up as well. Right now I just have bolts acting as pins holding the uppers onto the door, there is nothing for them to screw into.
I can't even do that in my YJ
Do I need some sort of spacer between my hard upper doors and the lower doors on a YJ? The doors don't seem to fit right even after adjusting the hinges.

This is correct. I used to work at a donut shop as a fry cook. Cake donuts come out of a dropper directly into the fryer and don't have the "dough hole". Regular donuts are cut out and then allowed to rise (we put ours in a hot box) and then fried.

I used to work at a donut shop as a fry cook and yes, they do, or at least ours did. There is a big roller machine you feed dough into and it cuts out the donut shape (or rather a octogon with a hole in the middle). The machine also cuts out a hole in the middle which is either used as donut holes or remixed into more dough for donuts.
It was a livestream, so maybe not.

Also I had wanted something manual, and I couldn't find one in the US that was, which leads me to believe we never got manual ones in the US.

Not offended at all, I just thought you were confusing the various militias with the National Guard. I don't disagree that National Guard soldiers are often subpar to Active Duty ones, but very often, National Guard soldiers are ex-active duty ones and many have seen more combat experience than a lot of active duty soldiers.
We've come a long long way as an Army since Vietnam and Kent State.
No they don't. But as we saw in Vietnam and Afghanistan, you don't need anywhere near the power of the US military to defeat it in asymetrical warfare.
The National Guard has Special Forces and an Air Force as well. It's not really much different from the regular army. They still have tanks, jets, drones, etc.

The National Guard is still part of the Army just FYI. They go to the same training (at least for BCT and AIT). They're just part time (with a few exceptions, such as the National Guard's Special Forces, and various maintenance positions). They are still professional soldiers, and can still deploy to Iraq, Afghanistan, etc.
You may be thinking of individual state militias which *are not* part of the Army/National Guard (or DoD for that matter). They usually fall under the oversight of the state governments or are non-governmental entities entirely. These a militias are the ones full of the "dudes who just like to dress in camo once a month".
Source: Former US Army National Guard

The 4cyl is fine. I own two '95 Yjs and both are 4 cylinders. Watch for rust. That's about it. '95 was the only year the body was galvanized, so they tend to be the least rusty. They aren't comfortable to drive, so keep that in mind.
